properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 3:59 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a severe thunderstorm capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and heavy rain. ### Large hail can damage property and cause injury. Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-03T23:58:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T20:59:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2770946660.2020
Area: Red Lake - Woodland Caribou Park, Kenora - Grassy Narrows - Whitedog
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot temperatures this evening, before a slight reprieve this weekend. Afternoon temperatures are forecast to reach at least 30 degrees Celsius today, with Humidex values near 36. A slight decrease in temperatures will occur tonight through the weekend. However, by early next week, temperatures reaching or exceeding 31 degrees during the day and remaining at or above 21 degrees at night, are expected to return. These extremes temperatures will likely persist through the entire week. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T09:59:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T19:18:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1854369177.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will continue over the Williston region today. An additional 5 mm is expected with 10 to 15 mm over higher terrain before rain tapers to a few showers this evening. 30 to 60 mm of rain has fallen over a broad swath of the BC Interior since early Wednesday morning. Please refer to the BC River Forecast Centre web page for the latest flood warnings and advisories: http://bcrfc.env.gov.bc.ca/warnings/index.htm ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T07:31:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T18:12:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3042088439.2020
Area: Williston
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected through the weekend into next week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected for the foreseeable future. Overnight lows near 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T11:17:30-00:00

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable late this afternoon and evening for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts and large hail. ### Strong wind gusts can toss loose objects, damage weak buildings, break branches off trees and overturn large vehicles. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm. For more information: http://www.emergencymanagementontario.ca/english/beprepared/beprepared.html.

properties.Title: Update: Dam Overflow Alert Issued By Riverdale Municipality
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Riverdale Municipality has issued a MANDATORY EVACUATION to the residents immediately adjacent to the Little Saskatchewan River. This evacuation includes all livestock. The evacuation is due to a possible dam failure at the RIVERS RESERVOIR DAM. All evacuees are to report to Municipal Office by phone at 204-328-5300 for further instruction.
Expires: 2020-07-10T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-03T15:31:15-05:00, 29F1F445-8F0A-44CC-0C99-6C679401C988
Area: Little Saskatchewan River in the Riverdale Municipality
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning For The Assiniboine River From Brandon To Portage La Prairie.
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure‚Äôs Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning for the Assiniboine River from Brandon to Portage la Prairie. If you are in the affected area, be watchful as local waterways are expected to rise quickly and may cause flooding. There is a potential for overland flooding in low lying areas. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Use caution when driving on all roads as road conditions may have changed. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by local authorities, listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Stay tuned to local media for updates.
Expires: 2020-07-06T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-03T15:56:40-05:00, C28858C9-9C4B-AD82-D12A-4BA813434569
Area: Assiniboine River from Brandon to Portage la Prairie
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Update: Dam Overflow Alert Issued By Manitoba Infrastructure In The Areas Of Riverdale Municipality And Rm Of Whitehead
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure is advising a possible dam failure at the RIVERS RESERVOIR DAM may occur within 24 hours. This will result in extreme flooding and dangerous situations. Residences in the affected area should prepare to evacuate if advised by the municipality. Avoid water bodies, valleys, low lying areas and affected areas. Move to higher ground if required and avoid flooded areas. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Use caution when driving on all roads as road conditions may have changed. Follow all directions by local authorities and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Stay tuned to local media for updates. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca.
Expires: 2020-07-10T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-07-03T15:29:31-05:00, E2600C0F-3A11-DF04-26FD-4DFE69469EDC
Area: Little Saskatchewan River in the Riverdale Municipality and RM of Whitehead.
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hot weather is expected through the weekend into early next week. Daytime high temperatures in excess of 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the high thirties to low forties, are expected until at least Sunday, and likely beyond. Overnight lows in excess of 20 degrees Celsius are also expected through this period, providing little relief from the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T06:50:16-00:00

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long duration heat event continues. Daytime high temperatures near 30 degrees Celsius, with humidex values in the mid to high thirties, are expected until Sunday, or possibly into early next week for some areas. Overnight lows near 19 degrees Celsius will provide little relief from the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T11:57:32-00:00

properties.Summary:

Overnight lows will range from 16 to 20 degrees Celsius. Areas near Lake Superior will have slightly cooler temperatures. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 34 are expected for the next 2 days. A hot and humid airmass persists over much of southern and east central Manitoba. A weather system will spread showers and thunderstorms into southern Manitoba tonight and Saturday, however east central regions will have more sunshine and thus will remain hot throughout most of the weekend. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links ‚Äì Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T12:41:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T20:42:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3447411315.2020

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long episode of rain, at times heavy, continues. A further 20 to 40 mm of rain is expected to fall today and tonight over the B.C. Peace River, Fort Nelson, and Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park regions. A persistent low pressure system over Alberta has led to several days of heavy rain over the B.C. Peace River, Fort Nelson, and Muncho Lake Park- Stone Mountain Park regions. So far in this rain event, 40 to 80 mm of rain has fallen over the region since Wednesday morning. The showers are expected to ease on Saturday as the low pressure system weakens. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T09:55:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T17:56:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3904038684.2020
Area: Muncho Lake Park - Stone Mountain Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event continues into early next week. Daytime high temperatures in the low thirties with humidex values in the mid to upper thirties are expected over the next several days. Overnight lows will range from 18 to 20 degrees Celsius. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T11:58:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T19:59:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1295399758.2020
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Blind River - Thessalon, Espanola - Killarney
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event will continue, possibly into the weekend. Inland from the Great Lakes, daytime high temperatures near 29 degrees Celsius, with humidex values near 36, are possible over the next few days. Overnight lows will range from 16 to 20 degrees Celsius. Areas near the Great Lakes will feel slightly cooler temperatures. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index approaching the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T11:58:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T19:59:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3240386096.2020
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of severe thunderstorms that may be capable of producing strong wind gusts, large hail and heavy rain. Thunderstorms are developing this afternoon along a trough of low pressure over southeastern Manitoba. Some of these thunderstorms may become severe. ### Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T03:55:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T19:57:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3818623096.2020

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: At 3:10 p.m. CDT, Environment Canada meteorologists are tracking a line of severe thunderstorms capable of producing very strong wind gusts, up to nickel size hail and torrential rain. This line stretches from Pointe du Bois south to Whitemouth and is nearly stationary. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Severe thunderstorm warnings are issued when imminent or occurring thunderstorms are likely to produce or are producing one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall.
Expires: 2020-07-03T23:09:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T20:11:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3276887437.2020
Area: R.M. of Whitemouth incl. Elma, Pointe du Bois, Falcon Lake and West Hawk Lake, R.M. of Reynolds incl. Ste. Rita Hadashville and Rennie
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hot temperatures again today, before a slight reprieve this weekend. Afternoon temperatures are forecast to reach at least 30 degrees Celsius today, with Humidex values near 36. A slight decrease in temperatures will occur tonight through the weekend. However, by Monday of next week, temperatures reaching or exceeding 31 degrees during the day and remaining at or above 21 degrees at night, are expected to return. These extremes temperatures will likely persist through the entire week. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-04T06:51:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-07-03T14:52:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3371554184.2020
